results.title: Painting with calligraphy
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Eliot O'Hara
results.brief_description: The history of calligraphy - or picture writing - in art is traced from prehistoric times to the present day. Varied used of calligraphy are shown in demonstrations by Eliot O’Hara, George Post, and Paul Travis, and in examples from the works of Burchfield, Dufy, Klee, Marin and Van Gogh.

results.title: Painting the Town
results.creator_credit: Ned Lander, Trevor Graham, Sharon Connolly and Charles Merewether
results.brief_description: This is a film about art and artists, culture and politics. Through the story of Yosl Bergner, the film reveals a community of Australian painters who sought to create an art that would reflect the great social upheavals of the 1930s and the 1940s. Yosl Bergner, Ruth Bergner, Jim Wigley and Albert Tucker discuss this period. Rated: G

results.title: Painting the Chinese landscape
results.creator_credit: China Film Enterprises of America and Wan-go Wen
results.brief_description: This film illustrates the four important steps in painting a Chinese landscape. Starting with a blank sheet of paper, we see the artist outline his layout, fill in his brush work, group together the related parts with shading, and finally retouch for emphasis.
results.creator_credit_for_label: China Film Enterprises of America and Wan-go Wen

results.title: Painting shadows
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Eliot O'Hara
results.brief_description: With demonstrations and teaching devices, Eliot O’Hara relates the physical laws of light to the specific needs of the art student. In his own painting of a two-storey white house in sunlight, Eliot O’Hara shows the application of the four basic elements of lighting: the direct light of the sun; shadow influenced by sky; shadow with reflected light, and shadow with very dim light.

results.title: Painting reflections in water
results.brief_description: This is the first of a series of films made in collaboration with Eliot O’Hara, distinguished American art teacher and artist. We see O’Hara painting the complete sketch, from blocking the composition in charcoal, applying water with a broad brush, until finally the artist has painted a bright picture that seems as “wet” as the harbour where it was painted, so naturalistic is O’Hara’s technique. This is a “how-to-do-it film”, the purpose of which is to demonstrate one particular artist’s technique not to indicate critical principles or aesthetic standards.

results.title: Painting people
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, Malcolm Otton and Tim Burstall
results.brief_description: Six Australian artists - William Dobell, Russell Drysdale, Clifton Pugh, William Dargie, Jan Molvig and Andrew Sibley - discuss the problems of portraiture, including paintings of Tom Roberts and Arthur Streeton.

results.title: Painting Landscape and Water in Oils
results.brief_description: A step-by-step guide showing the materials and techniques used by internationally famous artist, W.R. (Robin) Jennings. Although an artist of rare skill, Jennings is largely self-taught and his own thoughts on technique are enjoyable to follow. Notes which accompany this video cover helpful information on the equipment needed.

results.title: Painting crowds of people
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Eliot O'Hara
results.brief_description: In a series of watercolor demonstrations, Eliot O’Hara shows how to create impressions of crowds without defining individuals. He suggests various modes of interpretation - ways of capturing the patterns, colors, mood, and movement of crowds without details that might distract from the rhythm of a composition.

results.title: Painting clouds
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Eliot O'Hara
results.brief_description: Describes different types of clouds, their formation, and techniques used in painting them in water-colours.

results.title: Painting an abstraction
results.brief_description: Eliot O’Hara, American artist and teacher, presents his own technique of “abstracting” desired elements for a water-colour painting. He emphasises the careful arrangement of planes and colour in a unique pattern. The same subject - treated in the film “Painting reflections in water” is used to show how purpose influences choice and technique.
